featured.text: However, CGI has difficulties of its own, and there will always be a demand for the realism and thrilling 30 of an actual stunt.
Beginning around 1910, audiences developed a taste for serial action movies, which 26 the use of dedicated stunt people to perform in dangerous scenes.
So the stunt industry is probably in no immediate danger of dying off.
The 1960s and ’70s 28 the development of most modern stunt technology, like air rams and bullet squibs.
These people were not trained to perform stunts, so they often 24 things for the first time during the actual shooting.

other.text: Today, CGI (computer generated imagery) is widely used in filmmaking, and it is now 29 to create very lifelike scenes without using real stunt people.
Such demand increased with the rise of western movies, and many cowboys with masterful skills on horseback found a new 27 as a stunt person.
There were, however, no 23 crew members to perform impressive stunts at that time.
Stunt work emerged out of 22 over time.

definition.zh_def: 特技；驚人的表演或行為
definition.en_def: A performance involving difficult or dangerous actions, often used in films or shows.
definition.example: The actor performed an incredible stunt that left the audience in awe.
